description: An introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.
name: CELLULAR BIOLOGY AND BIOCHEMISTRY

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of
enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure
and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction,
motility, and the cell cycle.
Many students reported that this course featured “useful” information, which was
also “interesting material.” Students noted that “you will learn so much about the inner
workings of the cell,” agreeing that it was an incredibly informative class. Some students
did feel, however, that they were left with a “hazy understanding” of the material or that
it is something they “will likely forget in a few weeks.” The course was taught by
different teachers, which led students to comment that the course was “choppy and
disorganized” because of the different teaching styles.
Professor Schultz was “engaging” and “genuinely loves what he does.” However,
he was “disorganized” and went off on tangents frequently. In addition to that, one
student remarked that Professor Schultz “assumed a certain level of knowledge among
the students.” Professor Schultz did not hold weekly office hours, so many students
complained about his accessibility.
Students overwhelmingly found this course to be “very tough.” Students noted a
“disconnect between what was emphasized during the lectures and what was asked
during exams.” There was a “staggering” volume of information and level of detail
needed for the exams. One student noted that it was “difficult to gauge” the level of
understanding before an exam due to the disorganization of study materials.

This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of
enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure
and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction,
motility, and the cell cycle.
Many students reported that this course featured “useful” information, which was
also “interesting material.” Students noted that “you will learn so much about the inner
workings of the cell,” agreeing that it was an incredibly informative class. Some students
did feel, however, that they were left with a “hazy understanding” of the material or that
it is something they “will likely forget in a few weeks.” The course was taught by
different teachers, which led students to comment that the course was “choppy and
disorganized” because of the different teaching styles.
Students found Dr. Svitkina to be nice and “very knowledgeable,” but many
complained that she had “difficulty articulating her thoughts in English,” which often
made it difficult to follow her lectures. Additionally, many complained that she was
“very broad in her coverage of course material,” with an emphasis on “random trivia.”
Students also complained that Dr. Svitkina was not very accessible, as she had no
“regular office hours” and only held one review session all year.
Students overwhelmingly found this course to be “very tough.” They noted a
“disconnect between what was emphasized during the lectures and what was asked
during exams.” There was a “staggering” volume of information and level of detail
needed for the exams. One student noted that it was “difficult to gauge” the level of
understanding before an exam due to the disorganization of study materials.

An introduction to cellular biology and biochemistry, BIOL202 covers topics
including protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric
regulation of enzyme activity; cell structure and function including membrane structure,
membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility; and the cell cycle. Students should
have taken a general introductory biology course as well as have a strong background in
general chemistry. Although it is advisable to have some prior knowledge of organic
chemistry for a biochemistry course, it is not a necessary pre-requisite for the class.
Students should expect class lectures to follow closely with corresponding chapters in
Molecular Biology of The Cell by Taylor.
Most students felt that they had learned a lot from the course. Although many
thought that it required quite a bit of work to fully understand the material, students saw
the class as solid preparation for higher-level biology courses. It seems, in general,
students thought the course covered a great deal of material.
Professor Witmer received mostly positive reviews from her students. Although a
few remarked that lectures could be “disorganized” and not entirely consistent with the
textbook, the majority seemed to appreciate Professor Witmer’s efforts. Students were
very “impressed” by Professor Witmer’s teaching ability. One enthusiastic student noted,
“Dr. Witmer really goes above and beyond for her students. A professor like her who’s
constantly pushing her students to think critically is rare.” There were, however, mixed
views of the professor’s availability for help.
Because this was specifically the LPS section, it was targeted mainly towards
part-time students. Most students felt the class was very challenging and the only
complaints centered on the exams being very unpredictable. Because the material is quite
dense, prospective students should expect to put in a lot of work reading the text and
reviewing class notes.
